K5uKpGQJYsTKMCb1gnOp0w.text: Nestled in the heart of Pimlico, this little restaurant is the perfect place for a weekend brunch. The decor is warmed by wooden tables and tasteful prints. Delicious mains and a fine selection of wines. The staff are personable and an added touch is the series of staff portraits dating from the sixties that adorn the walls. If you haven't yet ventured into Grumbles I guarantee your palate (if not your wallet - it's a bit pricey!) will appreciate it!

Ce_Q5hmjwhe9k-nvSwE9NQ.text: Grumbles is one of the many restaurants in my neighborhood, and I have been a few times which is saying something, and each time I was not disappointed. The first time was with a girlfriend and we had a delicious Sauvignon Blanc from their great, yet affordable wine list. We had mains only, since the bread and olives presented upon arrival was a sufficient starter. the 95p charged to the bill to cover these was well worth it. I had the fish pie and she the filet. We were both thoroughly impressed. I will say I am an American transplant and this was my first experience with a fish pie and am officially now a fan. My friend ordered her filet with mash and cooked medium rare and she got just that. Which is nice considered how many places do not get medium rare right around here!On our most recent visit we did a pre-theatre dinner as we were actually going to the theatre.  Upon arrival we were informed the chef was in traffic and running late and it might be a while, but when we indicated we were going to the theatre we were assured that we would be served in plenty of time and we were. Three delicious courses later we were on our way to a show at 7:05. I must say three courses for 13.50 each in of itself was a feat. To start I had the beet, green bean and goat cheese salad and my husband had the cream of tomato soup (see photos). Both were delicious. Next I had the fish cake with greens and he had the pork belly with mash. My fishcake was perfectly assembled with chives, mash and fish (though I would have preferred a bit more fish). The pork belly, wasn't exactly what we were expecting, but then we weren't exactly sure what pork belly was.  I think my husband wished he had ordered the fish cake. But the topper of the night was the two apple pancakes, served with vanilla ice cream and whipped cream and strawberries. It really made me glad I hadn't eaten that waffle on Oxford Street I was considering that afternoon.  Because this was heaven on a plate, if you only come for one thing make it desert and a glass of wine.

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. beet, green beans and goat cheese starter salad
Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. creamed tomato soup

ti3CviiEG6DWyfhv-tZ83Q.text: A hidden treasure.  Just off the main road, this local spot has a cozy, intimate setting with tables close enough that you can keep yourself entertained by looking curiously at what other diners are eating.  The service was excellent, and the waiters didn't treat us out-of-towners any differently than the other patrons.  I ordered the Goat Cheese and Chicken Liver and Foie Gras Parfait as appetizers, and they literally melt in your mouth with taste.  The main entree, the duck confit, was also good but the apps really stole the show. Good value with food that could be found in much more expensive restaurants.

j8JoOA4xCH0fB0w1Tc5k3g.text: Grumbles has a great vibe indeed, and a very authentic feel. However, the food is a major disappointment and it's very overpriced to boot for what you get.We ordered a Haloumi salad with Mediterranean vegetables and the red lentil soup which was one of the days specials. The salad was a good idea in principle, but instead of a traditional Mideastern salad, I got what amounted to olive oil soup with a few overcooked vegetables; it was absolutely drenched in oil and rather disgusting. It was also not fresh and was clearly sitting in a fridge for some time. The actual red lentil soup was nice but not out of the ordinary.The service was pretty good and again, it felt like a great place to have a drink or something. But I don't think I'd go back for the food.

rCyEcaWu6jijm2uKIuIGJw.text: My girlfriend and I came here for dinner our first night in town. Grumbles was more of something that we chose after discovering that many places in London get booked up ahead of time for dinner, particularly on weekends. Getting seated was easy enough (we got a nice outdoors seat on a quiet street), and the service overall was okay.That said, the food was a bit disappointing, more so after getting some context around what else is available here in the UK. The best part about dinner was the appetizer, which was the seared scallops with watercress dressing. The scallops were cooked to just the right texture, and the dressing provided a light flavoring that accentuated their taste. The main courses though were disappointing. My girlfriend got fish and chips and was disappointed to get beer-battered fish that was unimaginative in taste and had plain tartare sauce to dip it in. I had the signature filet steak at grumbles, but it was overcooked (at least medium despite a request of medium-rare), and the marinade of English mustard and brown sugar would have been delicious...if applied more evenly. In quite a few spots there was way too much, and the reaction my taste buds had was not too dissimilar from that which one has after receiving a surprise dose of wasabi with their sushi - way, way too hot in certain instances. The side of mashed potatoes were hand-made but had to be the most flavorless potatoes I've had - I don't think any salt or butter were added at all.It's a nice little spot in the neighborhood, but the 50 pounds that the entire meal cost for the both of us was a bit on the steep side. I would probably try something else if I came back (or at least something that better reflects the value).

O_ly4YOE9CIujUxrQuyiQQ.text: Absolutely loved this place. Fun local crowd; relaxing, charming and inviting decor; good service; great food. Total hidden gem. We were on vacation in London and we had to go back two nights. Had a pork with stilton sauce that I am still craving a few months later. If I lived in London, I'd be a regular there.

VAfg8ISMyuQ9MDqHtfW_bQ.text: Only a day after arriving to London and we already found Grumbles. I'd say in general this was a wonderful restaurant for its food and atmosphere. For starters my wife and I shared a prawns and avocado dish. The ingredients were pretty fresh and ample yet I couldn't get over how the sauce drenched everything and tasted exactly like McDonald's special fry sauce.My wife had the fish and chips which was excellent: crisp, not greasy and warm. I had the leek and onion creamy risotto which was excellent and even felt refreshing on this warm summer night.Lastly, my only cautionary tale is about the service. I concede this could be an American perception however the problem is that our server removed our uneaten bread, butter and olives between appetiser and entree courses without a word or question. I'd say that since we paid 95p for those thing that we're entitled to enjoy them fully. Next meal we'll have to watch everything on the table carefully.

Xh8StDhBSzB3giHSC0kSUg.text: I absolutely adore this place.  It is small and very intimate with a handful of booths and tables and definitely has a bit of a dark and romantic feel with a good bistro feel influenced by a French bistro.  Everything was wonderful--a nice halloumi grilled cheese and vegetable starter, and a lovely duck breast main with divine sweet potatoes.  Everything was delicious, the service was great, and where else can you have 2 starters, two great mains, a side and a bottle of wine for 70 quid?  Atmosphere was great--just be weary of the table by the door on a cold eve.  I can't wait to get back.....

CMZExZxvBha1BSn36pRH2A.text: Splendid, smashing and totally scrummy. I would make fun of the name, but when it was the name of this place that made me and three others walk through the back roads of Pimlico to get to it, I can't really take many jibes at it.I mean, who WOULDN'T want to eat at a place named 'Grumbles'?  Especially after this person snoops over its menu posted outside and peers into the dark and candle lit interior to see happy diners mooching at their delicious and reasonably priced meals at the tables. I loved everything about this place.  From the quaint atmosphere to the quaint prices.  From the big flavours to the big wine list.  Sure, the menu wasn't wholly inspired by the isles.  Yes, we ordered tuna and haloumi.  But I can't think of a more quintessentially British dining experience.

Ca9gi2Ip3og8UboLAJ9W5g.text: Count on the British to take a fabulous restaurant: homey authentic decor, friendly staff, top-notch food, ridiculously fair pricing, splendid wine list, romantic cottage atmosphere, friendly staff... and downplay it with a name like Grumbles. I would say: "it was absolutely beautiful and splendid in every way."They would say -- "it wasn't bad."From fish pies to boozy puds, this place couldn't get more British if it tried. And I wouldn't change a thing. After a bottle of wine, two appetizers and four entrees later, we've yet to find something to grumble about...

nuXPI1nTNlDg5dKr1vUv-g.text: I think I found The Good Life.A genuinely happy place: The staff seemed happy, the owner seemed happy, the visiting wine suppliers seemed happy; I was certainly happy.  The food was excellent-- I mean tip-top, like you hope for in a posh place-- without all that stupid shit they stick on your plate to distract you.  Apparently (and supposedly) everything they serve is great.  I'd trust the staff with the wines-- they seem pretty in to them.  The place has a downstairs with bigger tables.There's a picture on the wall of an old guy who ate there every day til he died and I get it.  I suppose there's some sort of compliment in that I'm envying the dead.

_dvUlwqTPD2LUn6Hm9toGQ.text: This is one of my favourite place in Lodon. I am living nearby and it is so lucky that my favourite one is stone throw away from my place!Few months ago my mum visited with her friends and we traveled around Italy, France and Spain. Amongst every restaurants we visited in those countries, Grumbles was their favourite as well.So now, you can see how nice this place is!! :)

_KF4p0RNRcndoh0wEOXvTg.text: We are tourists from San Francisco area with two small kids. Would recommend. Went last  night and place was warm and accommodating. Waiter was supremely nice. When we asked for taste of a wine we were considering a bottle of, he brought over three glasses of half filled wine so we could try all the offerings of that varietal. Lovely bread and olives complementary. They have an early bird 2 course for £10.and 3 for €13. Super value. I had haddock, my husband the linguini. They were good, but not spectacular. All their dishes needed more oomph. But honestly it could just be that it's English food! I can't dock them for that. The mango sorbet and toffee ice cream were hits.  Very nice night. Made child sized portion (and priced less) for younger child too.

SUOV1Xw3SRkH0UGcpXXE8g.text: Went for Sunday lunch. Started with the potatoe and leek soup, which was a bit runnier than I usually like, but for the 'summer' season, it was nice and light. For the main I had the roast which was not huge, but a reasonable portion. The meat was not too fatty, the potatoes were ok, and the yorkshire pudding was not stale--all in all pretty good. Husband had the mackerel pate--which was delicious--and the grilled halloumi. While the cheese part was good, the rest of the salad was a bit lacking and the tomatoes were mushy and tasteless.Table was a bit cramped, but overall the ambiance was relaxed and the service really lovely.Be sure to check out the graffiti in the toilets--I really got a kick out of that.

g3AHDDHPWLu7HQ6CnJ3f4w.text: Delicious food.  Reasonably priced.  Super friendly.  Charming atmosphere.  Really enjoyed this place.

D_jon_Z9X-f5HOAAZKdIag.text: Top notch.  I just moved to the neighborhood and history had taught me to steer away from steaks in the UK.....not so at this place.  The house steak (Grumbles Filet) was to die for....crusted with English Mustard and Brown Sugar and truly cooked to perfection....medium was a warm pink center.   Paired with beautifully simple French Green Beans and pre-empted with an equally simple but none-the-less tasteful rocket & parmesean salad and I found a post-workout meal that I could be proud of.

gysMzG89hHgaQkY2RKjKnQ.text: This restaurant is a little gem; they serve proper English food at such friendly prices its ridiculous. The staff is warm and friendly and the place is jut adorable. When you are in you feel like you are in a cottage, its perfect for this cold days, but during the summer they have a lovely terrace and the street where it is quite calm and jolly. They usually have lunch specials and brunch specials as well. I always see them written on the black boards outside the restaurant. A great deal for great food.

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom

hDG-BmgX1F_KSB-EgTCQrg.text: I'm sorry I can't rate this place higher. We ate there two nights running. On the first we were delighted.  I had the lamb tagine, my wife had the grilled vegetables with feta and quinoa.  We both were delighted, so we went back the next night.  That time, we both had the grilled vegetables; however, this time both our servings were barely warm.  I complained to the person who appeared to be in charge who apologized and swept up the plates. We expected a new, warm start; but no, we got he same plates, obviously having been popped into the microwave. And then, she didn't even know which dish belonged to whom.  The taste was fine, but it all had left a bad taste that soured the overall experience.

YyfurFodtYZkxuHnJYwuJQ.text: You know that feeling when you go to France, turn right and pick any old restaurant? Sitting down you discover that the restaurant is the life and joy of its owners, and the surroundings are smothered in that grace and simplicity which arises when people focus on the important things like the food and the service, and leave the decor to just sort of fall into place. No sooner have you started eating, and you wonder ah. Why can't we have restaurants like this in the UK? Well, now we can. It's called Grumbles and it's in Pimlico. It's simply superb - great food, relaxed environment and fantastic service. They've even got a La Vache qui Rit sign on the wall amongst the other paraphernalia. It's a small cosy place perfect for that weekend lunch. Like a French bistro, they have a 3 course lunch menu for a tenner. Straying off this bumps the price a bit to around 25 per head including wine. All worth it.

485hE2BBWJzk5AXan_MR2Q.text: Went here for a sunday lunch and was not impressed. Slow service, and ludicrously overpriced for such below average food. Like stepping back into the 80s, and not in a good way.

laxlJEFMLBZo3IOyEWRsRQ.text: I really like this place, service was good even when its busy. Food was reasonably priced and very nice. I had the fish cakes which were lovely. Overall for a small restaurant close to Victoria it does well and you can see that as its quite busy most nights.

cctFqWS6C5TqYN-JnS8BNQ.text: Convenient walk from Luna Simone Hotel in Pimlico. This place was recommended in a Rick Steves guidebook. I ordered the scallops and the Grumbles steak. The food and service were great.

ob7j48CFRY0mWaOEDhSvYg.text: Grumbles is a really nice, down to earth, home-away-from-home local eatery. Food is delicious, and definitely for me some inspirational mixes of herbs that left me wanting more.Staff is courteous and friendly and the small street off a main road is residential, so you can sit outside and not get bogged down by passing cars.Food selection was just right, both the heavy and the lighter stuff and the wine card was just as it should be. Matched the food in both pricing and taste.I almost don't want to recommend it, because that'll make it more difficult for me to get a table ;)

uJavEQZ5MJJ6PDxGYscbhQ.text: Americans in London, staying on Gloucester Street.We were seated in the downstairs dining room.Small place.They had a hard time understanding what we wanted.Owner seemed hands on.Started with seared scallops and Potok and leek soup. Both were prepared well and very flavorful. Wife had lamb  special which came with root vegetables and potatoe, she loved it and couldn't finish it because it had too much meat. I got the chicken breast with cheese and asparagus but no starch included.Dessert was Eton Mess.All in all a good meal for a reasonable price although I was a little disturbed our waitress found us difficult to understand.We are from Boston.

9eSg0l4B8FygsXUsmVaLNA.text: Great food, great service, reasonable prices, cozy atmosphere. I will highly recommend this restaurant.

qwKowwbXkQcYAiYKpCrR9w.text: I was here in July '13 via a suggestion in Rick Steves' London book...and as with all of his suggestions, Grumbles did not disappoint! Everything was wonderful- from the food to the service to the wine. Loved the quaint atmosphere and the overall experience. I'd highly recommend.

Ka_7F8mMgQW58C6zy0raEg.text: We were looking for a place to eat in the Pimlico area. Our goddaughter's had been to Grumbles and gave it a two thumps up! We will agree it! We ordered the chicken salad and the fish and chips and were not disappointed! The setting is intimate. It was full when we got there but seating cleared as the evening went on.  It's nice to just sit and enjoy a meal and leave when you're ready. Another nice feature I didn't want to forget to mention was the music. Playlist was a kind of Rat Pack, Frank Sinatra, Sammy Davis Jr, Dean Martin tribute. Very nice!

BSiIsFv9YcFx0wvKmd7ASA.text: Cosy, friendly place. I ate from the specials menu and wasn't disappointed. Great staff and attentive service. Seemed to be comfortable catering for romantic couples and larger groups squashed around the tables, throughly recommend.

UWJI9J7GZ46Wl6SVh1jJbQ.text: Super great tasty food. Quite a complex menu for the size of the place, small and cozy. Nice service too. Plates were fairly priced and portions were perfect sized.We're out-of-towners staying with a friend nearby, came here with the wife who is American and shocked to see that nearly every customer in there was American too. Bizarre.

Bacb6eiSiKbwKPx7PKI2Vg.text: This place was nice, had good food, good service, and prices seem good for London (we spent £10-13 per person)

1jKfB_QAppfjaAAXIXBf2A.text: My wife and I ate dinner here on our first day in London and had a great time.  The restaurant is very cozy and inviting, with nice seating in the restaurant and outside on the sidewalk.  The food was delicious; everything from the first glass of wine to the last cup of coffee.  We had the grilled goat cheese, scallops, sea bass and lamb targine; all fantastic.  For dessert we had a special strudel with ice cream, which was a great finish to the evening.  Portions were very fair for the price and the quality was outstanding; I highly recommend Grumbles.

kRevNI42gW1ccGRdjz9WpA.text: A humble and cozy dinner spot in Pimlico, good for traditional British fare.  Our party ordered the fish pie, another fish dish, fish and chips, and chicken with cheddar cheese and asparagus(?).  The last dish was... creative.  The food was okay (a bit on the pricier side), but improved by the atmosphere of the restaurant.  A solid choice for dinner if you are in the area.

Rtb7aG3hwe0MYElZ26aVZQ.text: The reviews were pretty good on Yelp so I decided to give it a try, but unfortunately it wasn't worth the trip. The food wasn't bad, but it wasn't good either. The restaurant atmosphere was nice though and the staff was great.

mn6Egg5AVjlVZ6CyDnU70Q.text: Went here with 2 kids on our first night in London (from California) and everyone had a good meal. The fish pie was light and tasty. The service was good, and I liked that they had outdoor tables. Prices seemed reasonable.

3zCAvg3AEsGI6QlfqgXCsQ.text: After a very long day of navigating the London Underground, Portobello Rd, more underground (how dare they close the line we need on the day we're here?!), a nice quiet dinner was very much needed.Enter Yelp.  The very first restaurant I looked at was Grumbles.  A short walk from our hotel, check.  Review/, positive. ££ = "moderate price", and so off we go. It really IS a 5 minute walk! At 7:30 PM we were fortunate to get the last 2 topper table although I'm assuming there's a back room because people went in and never came back out.I was still not quite ready for dinner, so I ordered the soup of the day, cream of broccoli and an appetizer, which was 3 large scallops on a bed of butternut squash and a top of pancetta.  My husband ordered the rocket (arugula to us Americans) and Parmesan salad, and a lamb taggine dish.  Everything came out piping hot, well prepared and delicious.  We shared a crumble for dessert, raspberry and apple with a topping and then we poured cream over.  Again, piping hot and positively delectable.After an insanely busy day eating crowds, figuring out the London Underground, and walking our poor legs into mere sticks, this quiet, well modulated dinner was just what we needed.  In closing, we should have asked the reason this restaurant is named Grumbles.  It should be "Compliments" because I'm sure that's what everyone does who eats here!

VtcrIK67VGW1te9oeRZq4g.text: I showed up a little after 10:00pm, I had not expected to go here however they were open and I was hungry!I had the Liver, Bacon and Onions, it was excellent.  A side of mashed potatoes accompanied it.  My mom used to make Liver and Onions, so I had some expectations, they exceed them.  For dessert I ad a Sticky Date  pudding with Custard and Butterscotch sauce.  It was great, I've never had anything quite like it.The place was nice, there's a downstairs however I didn't see it.  Some art on the walls, including a man that looks like he's "grumbling", it made me smile.I would recommend a stop in here, they're open a little later that the average place around which is a plus, but just on food alone it's worth a stop.

5nsPolztPr30wIfLjwQKKQ.text: I'm an American who was staying in the Victoria area recently. This is a nice little gem in the Pimlico area, and we were quite happy with the food, service and ambiance!

PYm9-rxSfKQko_3faBJTig.text: More typical British, the atmosphere is nice and warm, the area is residential. The food is good and fairly priced. I had a fresh sea bass which was nice, good selection of wines, friendly staff

n0gPbuuoCiY66WPXHNy6NQ.text: Grumbles is a reliably good traditional British restaurant in Pimlico. I've been here many a time with work colleagues and it has never disappointed. They do a good value set menu (2 courses for around £12 I believe), the food is decent and the service friendly and quick.The interior is farmhouse-meets-church: the front door is thick varnished wood, with a mixture of benches that could have come straight from the pews of a nearby chapel. Thick candles add to the effect (there's no incense mind! Or organ-playing) and on the walls are old black and white prints circa turn of the 20th century. The crowd tend to be predominantly older residents of Belgravia, with the occasional tourist and nearby office worker.Overall, a dependable spot to get lunch or dinner.

vqvy_vOJIyuNy79LBydUQA.text: This was trainwreck of a dining experience: I'm actually food-depressed after eating here.Going in, the atmosphere looks a bit claustrophobic but the decor was standard enough. I was given bread and olives and noted the lack of flair in the free snacks.The menu looks like it has some promise...I opted for the green and white asparagus w/ quail egg and truffle aioli. BIG MISTAKE. I'd have to say this is probably one of the worst, most ill-conceived plates I've had in most of my life. There was no synergy, no quality, and one out of three of the quail eggs was runny. It was as if I was in a nightmare where someone who had never cooked before decided to feed me. Yes, it was that bad..and also 7 quid. The aioli was a viscous, tasteless mess.Then I was "treated" to a fishpie topped with whipped potatoes. While not as hellish as the aforementioned "Nightmare on Churton Street" it did little to assuage the tragedy on my tongue after the first course. Whatever fish was inside was no doubt of little quality, the gravy around it was flavorless, and the potatoes on top were created in such a way that appeared to be anathema to the art of cooking. This was bland on a new level.All this for the palty sum of 22 pounds (after "optional service" which felt odd, because I definitely didn't receive any..)"Eek! Methinks not" indeed.

kN7oBX1uGmCkhZF0Po9wtQ.text: Ate here as part of a group. We took of most of the tables in the basement. Restaurant is very cozy, in a good way. Had a three course meal: rabbit app, chicken pie entree, and cheese/biscuit dessert. Delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Cheese and biscuit dessert
Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Ice cream
Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Chicken pie and peas

qdpEv74CzD447qIV6qaevA.text: Very cozy place in a quiet street like village. Service is good, good is good. Very happy about the choice of the restaurant.

FSwrz7kQYvUQFeFBT0msmQ.text: Went here on a weekend night and luckily I made reservations as it was quite packed. This is a quaint little restaurant in London, with an old heritage. The place is small and historic, and the seating is a bit uncomfortable as the neighbouring tables almost lock you inside your seat for the duration of your meal. They are tight on space but that's not really surprising for London. I decided on the trout and got a salad as an appetizer. The food was prepared fast and fresh and you can definitely taste the quality of the food - a solid 3 stars. My trout tasted more like salmon, but it was still good nonetheless. However, I found this place to be extremely pricey. Not uncommon in Europe, but they charge an automatic 1-2 pound 'cover' for the table bread and olives...which is always a bit of a surprise when the bill comes.

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Trout

C7g1vh7l5suVuo8O5Pk_Lg.text: We both really enjoyed our dinner here. It was our last sit-down meal in London before moving on to the next city. When we arrived, the dining room upstairs was warm and packed. The first employee we met said we could wait for a few minutes for a table near the door to clear out, or we could find a spot to eat downstairs, where it was less crowded.Down the stairs we went! The basement seating area is a lot cozier than the dining room upstairs, which was totally fine for us. It was quiet - only one other party was seated when we entered - and it was warm. They have a bar, and food is transported from the kitchen via dumbwaiter (something I find so charming about London restaurants!) For dinner, I went with the chicken breast (it came smothered in cheddar cheese, mushrooms, and asparagus), and my husband went with the Moroccan lamb tagine. We ordered a couple of pints to round out our meal.The food was very good. We didn't have to wait long for the dumbwaiter to ding, announcing the arrival of our meals. My plate didn't look like much - I mean really, you can't make a dish smothered in wine sauce and cheese look pretty - but the flavors were definitely there. The chicken was grilled separately, then topped with the mushrooms, white wine sauce, and asparagus, before the melted cheese was added. As a final touch, they torched the cheese to give it a bit more oompf, which absolutely added to the flavor profile.My husband was pleasantly surprised by the quality of his own meal. The lamb was served on a bed of couscous, with vegetables and a cool yogurt dip on the side. He managed to destroy the plate in record time, though at one point he did pull something that looked suspiciously like a human hair out of the plate. He managed to convince himself it wasn't a hair, though, and almost licked the plate clean.And because we weren't full enough, we decided to order dessert. Last night in London, have to make it special, right? They didn't have sticky toffee pudding on the menu, so we went with the lime cheesecake. It was tasty (and definitely the prettiest presentation of food that night). The lime was offset by a mango sauce, which helped balance the tartness. The only reason I've taken off a star is the fact that our waitress - who was responsible only for the downstairs area (all two parties) - wasn't very attentive. The party behind us kept having to call her over to ask for more water, more wine, status on their meals and to ask for the dessert menu. We weren't quite as vocal, but we did have to flag her down a few times throughout the night, as well. The last time I tried to get her attention, she was on her phone...Despite all that, the food was excellent and we left feeling full and fuzzy. Had it not been our last night in town, we definitely would have gone back for another meal.

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Lime cheesecake
Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Moroccan Lamb
Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Chicken breast, smothered

a0s0x2T_NRQHQY1E_OCalQ.text: Make a reservation! This place is cozy and popular, but for good reason. The Grumbles Filet was so good we came back for a second night! Crusted with spicy mustard and brown sugar, each of our steaks were perfectly prepared. They also had this amazing fruit parfait dessert, which can only be described as "magical."We came across Grumbles after a long work day and no one was committing to picking a spot. I read the good reviews and saw that the prices were reasonable and that it was nearby our hotel by Pimlico. We are happy to have found it!

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Heavenly dessert!

k_gCx9Ax8Hgxd9Jyw_VhzQ.text: Open late! Food is good and exactly what I wanted.  Nice, local diner feel with a very very nice staff.  I got fish and chips. Don't judge me, but isn't that the best kind of late night eat after a couple of pints?

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom

7hAFcoFxKdbwejFSY86-CQ.text: Really great food. We sat outside so I can't comment on the ambiance but it looked nice. Had the fresh mozzarella and tomato salad as a starter. Fillet of sea bass over Mediterranean veggies as main.  Nice half bottle of Chianti. Penny had the same. Super service and the food was excellent.

oBj-DEHzgZ-cOtMRbsMpgg.text: Very inviting little place that oozes comfort food and warmth. After a warm welcome, I sat at a window table and was promptly served olives and bread - big doorstops of freshly baked loveliness. I ordered the avocado & prawn starter, fish pie and a glass of rose. The service was friendly and efficient and my enquiry about mussels in the pie handled quickly and courteously.The fish pie was light and devoid of all the cream and butter you might expect. The fish was the star with a solid supporting cast of smooth potato (complete with crispy top), dill and chives. The French guy at the next table was clearly relishing the escargot - quite the endorsement!For dessert I had the chocolate & brandy mousse. It looked huge, but miraculously it soon disappeared. I don't usually go for chocolate but this was worth making the exception. The bill came to £33 including a 12.5% service charge which is great value - anywhere, not just in London.  A great experience made even more so as I was dining alone and hardly even noticed!

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom

fSccjc7ik3AHfEhbh_jwsw.text: Classic British food with a modern twist....Had a very good meal on our first night in London. Had to go with Bangers and Mash and was not disappointed. Huge portion and the gravy was thick and delicious. Nice wine selection. Also had a pate as a first course and a cheese plate for dessert. Everyone at our table enjoyed their meal. We were part of a large group, so we ate downstairs. A bit cramped, so try and eat upstairs, if you can. A fine place to experience good quality English fare.

photos.caption: Photo of Grumbles - London, United Kingdom. Bangers and mash

EuhguDiQuRHUWe8vb7-W8A.text: Food and wine were delicious. Prices were great for the quality. The staff was pleasant, yet they seemed more attentive to other parties. We were going to order more but they didn't check back with us. I would go back again. Also, I would advise a reservation. Good luck, and happy eating!

3P3rEMEU2Uyr8PShBfszug.text: We kinda stumbled across this place rather late on this Sunday evening...  What a fabulous surprise!  The food was top-notch and priced so reasonably.  Same goes for the wine list.The staff was pleasant, accommodating and eager-to-please...#fishpie

j24aiv7kvsLkTrabrqT81w.text: A bit disappointed here, after all the glowing yelp reviews.  Pluses- olives on the table, very good bread and butter, nice glass of red wine, tasty rocket salad, good Eton Mess dessert, excellent service. Sadly, the entrees just weren't very tasty (fish pie and mullet with potatoes), and the tables are super tight and awkward.  We did enjoy the music they had playing.

lxlE_Gyti8w4GXfSDfMK3A.text: We were looking for s family place to eat. This place is very accommodating and lotsa  dishes to choose from. We will definitely eat here again.

X2zowy2y662Xq1DUXmwm0A.text: We had a wonderful dinner here on a rainy evening. Excellent service; very ample portions. My husband had a starter of chicken liver pâté, which he really enjoyed. I had a shrimp and avocado starter. It was much more generous than I expected. Our main dishes were vegetable lasagne and Moroccan lamb tagine: both very good, although I would have preferred more spice to the tagine. Nice wine list. We would definitely return. Reservations are highly recommended.

FQ-axOXnpCS0H0ycHPIl8g.text: Great place! Small but homey feel. Food is the best we've had so far in London. Get the Rose with your meal. Well definitely stop by again before we leave the country.

Doj-aaRWkIJz_n58Q-x3JQ.text: Apparently they don't like to serve singles. I went in after reading good reviews on Yelp and was turned away, saying they "had a large party in back and had no seats". Which was fine, but as I left I saw people walking in and getting seated. Btw there were open tables in the place. Sorry if my singleness offends you. My money spends just as good, which I took around the corner to a place that was happy to see me.

us30KIbK5rucPesTE10hkg.text: I was not a fan of my dish but my dining companion enjoyed theirs. I ordered the lamb and was disappointed. No where on the menu description was curry mentioned and the entire entree taste of curry. It was disappointing as the only food I was not in the mood for was Indian. My mother had the chicken with avocado and really enjoyed it. I tried a bite and was underwhelmed. They do not have a beer menu in the basement so I was under the impression they did not serve beer. I saw other patron drinking beer so I was a bit confused. Grumbles is okay.

qe01ZxEDLul7t7hi86_lLQ.text: I had really high hopes for Grumbles since most reviews were very good to excellent, but I came out a little disappointed!Firstly I would say I love the rustic interior and thought the meal would be some delicious rustic, comfort food to match the decor. I ordered the snails and the fish pie whilst my friend ordered the prawns in garlic and chili and the burger with fries. The snails were lovely and so were the prawns, so far so good with the starters! If we had left at that point Grumbles would have had top marks but we were hungry and had mains! Firstly my fish pie, it was very blend and didn't taste as if the mash potatoes and the fish had come across any seasoning. I added salt and pepper and it was fine. My friend barely ate any of her burger as the whole plate, in contrast with mine, was just pure salt! The waitress though was lovely and asked why she hadn't eaten any of her burger and when my friend explained, she offered to order another dish. They handled this situation very well and that I was very pleased with.

iyQaNen-VDGkzy2rmjZUTg.text: It's really a three and a half stars.   Traveling on business.  Was looking for a homey place serving typical British fare.  Grumbles is the place.    Seating is limited but there is also a basement with additional tables.   I went there on a Monday evening but the place was jam-packed.    Looked around and impression was that the patrons were mostly local (or at least not from out of country).  Good selection on the menu.  I ordered Avocado with shrimps as appetizer which was okay.  Fish pie was quite good.  Generous portion and lots of flavours.

QTI49TlFgVu_OAUSMt0n_A.text: Delicious steak that was cooked perfect medium rare. House red wine was inexpensive and very tasty. Very easy to spend a couple hours relaxing and talking while having dinner.

yMQ8UIr5YaIWGHFA37rVSQ.text: Solid three stars. The atmosphere is lovely - a surprisingly cosy, nice place to sit and enjoy a leisurely meal. And I do mean leisurely - no one took our order for 40 minutes! And it took us about 15-20 minutes to order tea/coffee after our dishes were cleared. The food was good, not great. Well, actually - some dishes were great and others were pretty bad. It seemed very hit or miss; my scallop appetiser was delicious but overpriced (£9 for 3 small scallops), but my salad was pretty bad: it was slathered in a very strong mustard dressing to the point that I couldn't taste anything else, with the exception of saltiness from the otherwise tasteless halloumi. My dessert (vanilla ice cream with hot chocolate sauce and almonds) was served very prettily and was rich and yummy. It was just a shame that my main was so bad. Other comments from my table included:"Well, a fish pie is a fish pie, so it was fine.""My shrimp appetiser was amazing!"and "The creme brulee was alright."Basically, it's not a place I'd seek out.. but I also wouldn't be against giving it another try if I was in the area. Just a matter of hit or miss on the dishes.
